**Aruna Asaf Ali** (16 July 1909 – 29 July 1996), born **Aruna Ganguly** , was
an [Indian](/wiki/India "India") independence activist. She is widely
remembered for hoisting the [Indian National
Congress](/wiki/Indian_National_Congress "Indian National Congress")
[flag](/wiki/Flag_of_India#History "Flag of India") at the [Gowalia
Tank](/wiki/Gowalia_Tank "Gowalia Tank") maidan in [Bombay](/wiki/Bombay
"Bombay") during the [Quit India Movement](/wiki/Quit_India_Movement "Quit
India Movement"), 1942.

After Independence, she remained active in politics, becoming
[Delhi](/wiki/Delhi "Delhi")'s first mayor in 1958. In the 1960s, she
successfully started a media publishing house.

She received India's highest civilian award, the [Bharat
Ratna](/wiki/Bharat_Ratna "Bharat Ratna"), posthumously in 1997.

## Early life[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Aruna_Asaf_Ali&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Early life")]

Aruna Asaf Ali was born (Aruna Ganguly) on 16 July 1909 in Kalka,
[Punjab](/wiki/Punjab_\(British_India\) "Punjab \(British India\)"), [British
India](/wiki/British_India "British India") (now in [Haryana](/wiki/Haryana
"Haryana"), India) into a [Bengali](/wiki/Bengali_people "Bengali people")
[Brahmo](/wiki/Brahmo "Brahmo") family. Her father Upendranath Ganguly hailed
from [Barisal district](/wiki/Barisal_district "Barisal district") of Eastern
[Bengal](/wiki/Bengal "Bengal") (now [Bangladesh](/wiki/Bangladesh
"Bangladesh")) but settled in the United Province. He was a restaurant owner.
Her mother Ambalika Devi was the daughter of [Trailokyanath
Sanyal](/wiki/Trailokyanath_Sanyal "Trailokyanath Sanyal"), a renowned Brahmo
leader who wrote many Brahmo hymns. Upendranath Ganguly's younger brother
[Dhirendranath Ganguly](/wiki/Dhirendranath_Ganguly "Dhirendranath Ganguly")
(D G) was one of the earliest film directors.[1] Another brother,
Nagendranath, was a university professor who married [Nobel Prize
winner](/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Literature "Nobel Prize in Literature")
[Rabindranath Tagore](/wiki/Rabindranath_Tagore "Rabindranath Tagore")'s only
surviving daughter Mira Devi.[2] Aruna's sister [Purnima
Banerjee](/wiki/Purnima_Banerjee "Purnima Banerjee") was a member of the
[Constituent Assembly of India](/wiki/Constituent_Assembly_of_India
"Constituent Assembly of India").

Aruna was educated at Sacred Heart Convent in [Lahore](/wiki/Lahore "Lahore")
and then at [All Saints' College](http://www.allsaintscollege.org/) in
[Nainital](/wiki/Nainital "Nainital"). After her graduation, she worked as a
teacher at the [Gokhale](/wiki/Gopal_Krishna_Gokhale "Gopal Krishna Gokhale")
Memorial School in [Calcutta](/wiki/Calcutta "Calcutta"). She met [Asaf
Ali](/wiki/Asaf_Ali "Asaf Ali"), a leader in the Congress party, in
[Allahabad](/wiki/Allahabad "Allahabad"). They got married in 1928, despite
parental opposition on grounds of religion and age (he was a
[Muslim](/wiki/Muslim "Muslim") and her senior by more than 20 years).[3]

> My father was no more when Asaf and I married in September 1928. My paternal
> uncle Nagendranath Ganguly, a university professor who regarded himself as
> my guardian, said to relatives and friends that as far as he was concerned I
> was dead and he had performed my _[shraddh](/wiki/%C5%9Ar%C4%81ddha
> "Śrāddha")_.[4]
>
> — Aruna Asaf Ali

## Freedom struggle: early
days[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Aruna_Asaf_Ali&action=edit&section=2 "Edit
section: Freedom struggle: early days")]

She was an active member of [Congress Party](/wiki/Indian_National_Congress
"Indian National Congress") after marrying Asaf Ali and participated in public
processions during the [Salt Satyagraha](/wiki/Salt_Satyagraha "Salt
Satyagraha"). She was arrested on the charge that she was a
[vagrant](/wiki/Vagrancy_\(people\) "Vagrancy \(people\)") and hence not
released in 1931 under the [Gandhi-Irwin Pact](/wiki/Gandhi-Irwin_Pact
"Gandhi-Irwin Pact") which stipulated release of all political prisoners.
Other women co-prisoners refused to leave the premises unless she was also
released and gave in only after [Mohandas K. Gandhi](/wiki/Mohandas_K._Gandhi
"Mohandas K. Gandhi") intervened. A public agitation secured her release.

In 1932, she was held [prisoner](/wiki/Political_prisoner "Political
prisoner") at the Tihar Jail where she protested the indifferent treatment of
political prisoners by launching a hunger strike. Her efforts resulted in an
improvement of conditions in the Tihar Jail but she was moved to
[Ambala](/wiki/Ambala "Ambala") and was subjected to solitary confinement. She
was politically not very active after her release, but at the ending of 1942,
she took part in the underground movement. She was active in it.

## Face of Quit India
movement[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Aruna_Asaf_Ali&action=edit&section=3 "Edit
section: Face of Quit India movement")]

On 8 August 1942, the [All India Congress
Committee](/wiki/All_India_Congress_Committee "All India Congress Committee")
passed the [Quit India resolution](/wiki/Quit_India_Movement "Quit India
Movement") at the [Bombay](/wiki/Bombay "Bombay") session. The government
responded by arresting the major leaders and all members of the [Congress
Working Committee](/wiki/Congress_Working_Committee "Congress Working
Committee") and thus tried to pre-empt the movement from success. Young Aruna
Asaf Ali presided over the remainder of the session on 9 August and hoisted
the Congress flag at the Gowalia Tank Maidan. This marked the commencement of
the movement. The police fired upon the assembly at the session. Aruna was
dubbed the _Heroine of the 1942 movement_ for her bravery in the face of
danger and was called _Grand Old Lady of the Independence movement_ in her
later years. Despite the absence of direct leadership, spontaneous protests
and demonstrations were held all over the country, as an expression of the
desire of India’s youth to achieve independence.

## Countdown to
Independence[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Aruna_Asaf_Ali&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Countdown to Independence")]

An arrest warrant was issued in her name but she went underground to evade the
arrest and started an underground movement in the year 1942. Her property was
seized and sold. In the meanwhile, she also edited _Inquilab_ , a monthly
magazine of the Congress Party, along with [Ram Manohar
Lohia](/wiki/Ram_Manohar_Lohia "Ram Manohar Lohia"). In a 1944 issue, she
exhorted youth to action by asking them to forget futile discussions about
violence and [non-violence](/wiki/Non-violence "Non-violence") and join the
revolution. Leaders such as [Jayaprakash Narayan](/wiki/Jayaprakash_Narayan
"Jayaprakash Narayan") and Aruna Asaf Ali were described as "the Political
children of Gandhi but recent students of [Karl Marx](/wiki/Karl_Marx "Karl
Marx")." The government announced a reward of 5,000 [rupees](/wiki/Rupees
"Rupees") for her capture. She fell ill and was for a period hiding in Dr.
Joshi's Hospital in Karol Bagh in Delhi. Mahatma Gandhi sent her a hand-
written note to her to come out of hiding and surrender herself – as her
mission was accomplished and as she could utilize the reward amount for the
[Harijan](/wiki/Harijan "Harijan") cause. However, she came out of hiding only
after the warrant against her was withdrawn in 1946. She treasured the note
from the Mahatma and it adorned her drawing room. However, she also faced
criticism from Gandhi for her support of the [Royal Indian Navy
Mutiny](/wiki/Royal_Indian_Navy_Mutiny "Royal Indian Navy Mutiny"), a movement
she saw as the single greatest unifying factor of Hindus and Muslims at a time
that was the peak of the movement for Pakistan.

## Post-
Independence[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Aruna_Asaf_Ali&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Post-Independence")]

She was a member of the [Congress Socialist
Party](/wiki/Congress_Socialist_Party "Congress Socialist Party"), a
[caucus](/wiki/Caucus "Caucus") within the [Congress
Party](/wiki/Indian_National_Congress "Indian National Congress") for
activists with [socialist](/wiki/Socialist "Socialist") leanings.
Disillusioned with the progress of the Congress Party on socialism she joined
a new party, [Socialist Party](/wiki/Socialist_Party_\(India\) "Socialist
Party \(India\)") in 1948. She, however, left that party along with [Edatata
Narayanan](/wiki/Edatata_Narayanan "Edatata Narayanan") and they visited
[Moscow](/wiki/Moscow "Moscow") along with [Rajani Palme
Dutt](/wiki/Rajani_Palme_Dutt "Rajani Palme Dutt"). Both of them joined the
[Communist Party of India](/wiki/Communist_Party_of_India "Communist Party of
India") in the early 1950s. On the personal front, she was bereaved when Asaf
Ali died in 1953.

In 1954, she helped form the [National Federation of Indian
Women](/wiki/National_Federation_of_Indian_Women "National Federation of
Indian Women"), the women's wing of CPI but left the party in 1956 following
[Nikita Khrushchev](/wiki/Nikita_Khrushchev "Nikita Khrushchev")'s disowning
of Stalin. In 1958, she was elected the first [Mayor](/wiki/Mayor "Mayor") of
[Delhi](/wiki/Delhi "Delhi"). She was closely associated with social activists
and secularists of her era like Krishna Menon, Vimla Kapoor, [Guru Radha
Kishan](/wiki/Guru_Radha_Kishan "Guru Radha Kishan"), Premsagar Gupta, Rajani
Palme Joti, Sarla Sharma and Subhadra Joshi for social welfare and development
in Delhi.

She and Narayanan started Link publishing house and published a daily
newspaper, _Patriot_ and a weekly, _Link_ the same year. The publications
became prestigious due to the patronage of leaders such as [Jawaharlal
Nehru](/wiki/Jawaharlal_Nehru "Jawaharlal Nehru"), [Krishna
Menon](/wiki/Krishna_Menon "Krishna Menon") and [Biju
Patnaik](/wiki/Biju_Patnaik "Biju Patnaik"). Later she moved out of the
publishing house due to internal politics, stunned by greed taking over the
creed of her comrades. In 1964, she rejoined the Congress Party but stopped
taking part in active politics. Despite reservations about the
[emergency](/wiki/Indian_Emergency "Indian Emergency"), she remained close to
[Indira Gandhi](/wiki/Indira_Gandhi "Indira Gandhi") and [Rajiv
Gandhi](/wiki/Rajiv_Gandhi "Rajiv Gandhi").

She died in [New Delhi](/wiki/New_Delhi "New Delhi") on 29 July 1996, aged
87.[5]

## Legacy[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Aruna_Asaf_Ali&action=edit&section=6 "Edit
section: Legacy")]

Aruna Asaf Ali was awarded [International Lenin Peace
Prize](/wiki/International_Lenin_Peace_Prize "International Lenin Peace
Prize") for the year 1964[6] and the [Jawaharlal Nehru Award for International
Understanding](/wiki/Jawaharlal_Nehru_Award_for_International_Understanding
"Jawaharlal Nehru Award for International Understanding") in 1991.[7] She was
awarded India’s second highest civilian honour, the [Padma
Vibhushan](/wiki/Padma_Vibhushan "Padma Vibhushan") in her lifetime in 1992,
and finally the highest civilian award, the [Bharat Ratna](/wiki/Bharat_Ratna
"Bharat Ratna"), [posthumously](/wiki/Posthumous_recognition "Posthumous
recognition") in 1997.[8] In 1998, a stamp commemorating her was issued.
_Aruna Asaf Ali marg_ in [New Delhi](/wiki/New_Delhi "New Delhi") was named in
her honour. [All India Minorities Front](/wiki/All_India_Minorities_Front "All
India Minorities Front") distributes the _Dr Aruna Asaf Ali Sadbhawana Award_
annually.
